journal-meta.journal-title: The American Journal of Sports Medicine

title-group.subtitle: A New Measurement to Define the Position of the Tibial Tubercle in Patients With Patellar Dislocation

article-meta.aff: †General Hospital Oberndorf, Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, Oberndorf, Austria
‡General & Orthopaedic Hospital Stolzalpe, Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, Stolzalpe, Austria
§Institute for CT and MR imaging am Schillerpark, Linz, Austria

The study was performed at General & Orthopaedic Hospital Stolzalpe, Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, Stolzalpe, Austria

author-notes.corresp: *Gerd Seitlinger, MD, General Hospital Oberndorf, Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, Paracelsusstraße 37, A-5110 Oberndorf, Austria (e-mail:dr.seitlinger@aon.at).

permissions.copyright-holder: American Orthopaedic Society for Sports Medicine

abstract.p: Background: In patients with patellar instability, a pathological tibial tubercle–trochlear groove (TT-TG) distance is a risk factor. However, the TT-TG distance gives no information about the location of the malformation.
Hypothesis: Not all patients with a pathological TT-TG distance (≥20 mm) had lateralization of the tibial tubercle.
Study Design: Cohort study (diagnosis); Level of evidence, 2.

Methods: Fifty-eight knees in 49 patients with 2 or more patellar dislocations and 60 knees in 30 volunteers with no history of dislocation were analyzed using magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). The tibial tubercle–posterior cruciate ligament (TT-PCL) distance was defined as the mediolateral distance between the tibial tubercle midpoint and the medial border of the posterior cruciate ligament. The distance was measured parallel to the dorsal aspect of the proximal tibia (dorsal tibia condylar line). Three observers performed the measurements. Significant differences in the TT-PCL distance between the patient and the control group were estimated using an unpaired t test. The inter- and intraobserver variability of the measurement was performed.

Results: The intraclass correlation coefficients for inter- and intraobserver variability of the TT-PCL distance were higher than 0.74 and 0.93, respectively. A statistically significant difference (P < .05) was found between the TT-PCL distance in the control group (mean [SD], 18.4 [3.35] mm) and in patients (21.9 [4.30] mm). The mean (SD) TT-TG was 18.9 (5.16) mm in the patient group and 11.9 (4.67) mm in the control group (P < .05). In the control group, 95% had a TT-PCL distance <24 mm. In the patient group, 22 of 58 knee joints (38%) had a TT-PCL distance ≥24 mm. Seventeen of 40 knee joints (43%) with a TT-TG distance ≥20 mm had a TT-PCL distance <24 mm.

Conclusion: Only 57% of the patients with a pathological TT-TG distance (≥20 mm) had lateralization of the tibial tubercle in relation to the posterior cruciate ligament. The TT-PCL distance is an alternative method for determining the position of the tibial tubercle.

body.p: Distal realignment procedures are well-established surgical treatments for patients with patellar instability. One of the first was performed in 1888 by César Roux.15 This technique was subsequently modified by several authors.4-6,8,10

Clinically, a larger Q-angle is often found in these patients, but unfortunately, this finding is difficult to quantify.18 In 1978, Goutallier et al9 described the tibial tubercle–trochlear groove (TT-TG) distance, for which they measured the mediolateral distance between the anterior TT and the deepest point of the TG on an axial radiograph with the knee flexed at 30°. This made it possible to quantify lateralization of the tibial tubercle or medialization of the trochlear groove for the first time.

Nowadays, computed tomography (CT) allows more precise measurements by superimposing 2 CT slices (one through the distal femur and the other through the proximal tibia in the transverse plane). A TT-TG distance exceeding 20 mm is a factor for patellar instability. Therefore, a distal realignment procedure is a treatment option for symptomatic patients.3

In recent years, advanced radiological techniques have made it possible to image the patellofemoral joint in different flexion angles. Current literature shows that the position of the tibia relative to the femur changes during flexion.13,14,19 This suggests that the TT-TG distance varies as a function of knee flexion. On the other hand, it is sometimes difficult to define the deepest point of a dysplastic trochlea, making the measurement less reproducible in such patients.12 Moreover, this parameter gives no information about the location of the malformation. A high TT-TG might result because of a lateralization of the tibial tubercle or a medialization of the trochlear groove.

The purpose of this study was to introduce a new measurement that could be used to quantify the position of the tibial tubercle independent of the shape of the trochlea and with respect to the tibia only. The hypothesis was that not all patients with a pathological TT-TG distance (≥20 mm) have lateralization of the tibial tubercle.
If the hypothesis is proven true, this measurement could be used to offer a more accurate indication when distal realignment operations are appropriate.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: After approval was obtained from the institutional review board, data were collected retrospectively. All participants gave written informed consent.

We analyzed magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans of knee joints of 2 groups. The first (patient) group included 49 patients (58 knee joints) with 2 or more episodes of lateral patellar dislocation suggested by several physicians, orthopaedic surgeons, and prior imaging studies and confirmed with an orthopaedic examination by the primary author. The patients were recruited after their consultation between February 2007 and December 2010. Patients with prior surgery for patellar realignment were excluded. The mean age of the patients was 23.5 years (range, 12-37 years). Forty-three patients (88%) were female. The second (control) group comprised 30 volunteers (60 knee joints) with no history of injury or pain in their lower extremity. This was confirmed with a full orthopaedic examination of both lower extremities performed by the primary author (G.S.) and the senior author (S.H.). The control group had a mean age of 23.1 years (range, 17-47 years). Twenty-three volunteers (77%) were female. They were enrolled and examined in January 2009.

sec.title: Measurement
sec.p: Image analysis was performed by an orthopaedic surgeon and a radiologist, each with 6 years of MRI experience, and a general practitioner with poor MRI experience. All analysts were blinded to the participants’ data and study group. The images were presented randomly. The points on MRI were picked by each individual reader with digital software. One month later, the orthopaedic surgeon examined all of the MRI studies twice more. Image analysis was performed using a Philips ViewForum workstation (Philips, Andover, Massachusetts).

The tibial tubercle–posterior cruciate ligament (TT-PCL) distance was defined as the mediolateral distance between the midpoint of the insertion of the patellar tendon and the medial border of the PCL. The distance was measured parallel to the dorsal aspect of the proximal tibia–dorsal tibia condylar line (tangent to the proximal tibia below the joint and above the head of the fibula) (Figure 1). The point of the PCL was defined in the most inferior slice in which the ligament could still be clearly identified, which corresponds with the insertion of the ligament at the tibia (Figure 2A). The dorsal condylar line of the tibia was defined based on the work of Galland et al,7 just below the articular surface of the tibia plateau and above the fibular head (Figure 2B). The reference point of the tibial tubercle was located by marking the midpoint of the insertion of the patellar tendon (Figure 2C). Using the same reference point for the tibial tubercle, we measured the distance to the trochlear groove, parallel to the dorsal femoral condylar line (TT-TG distance) (Figure 3), which is comparable with the distance measured in a CT scan.17 In addition, we measured the femur torsion (Figure 4) and tibia torsion (Figure 5) according to Schneider et al,16 the alignment of the leg (angle between a line from the center of the femoral head to the center of the knee and a line from the center of the ankle to the center of the knee; positive values = varus, negative values = valgus) (Figure 6), the rotation of the knee joint (angle between tibia condylar line and dorsal femoral condylar line)7 (Figure 7), the lateral patellar tilt angle (LPTA) (Figure 8), and the sulcus angle11 (Figure 9) on MRI.

caption.p: TT-PCL measurement. The TT-PCL distance is the mediolateral distance between the midpoint of the insertion of the patellar tendon and the medial border of the posterior cruciate ligament parallel to the dorsal tibia condylar line (tangent to the proximal tibia below the joint and above the head of the fibula). dTCL, dorsal tibia condylar line; PCL, posterior cruciate ligament; TT-PCL, tibial tubercle–posterior cruciate ligament distance.

Tibial tubercle–posterior cruciate ligament (TT-PCL) measurement. (A) White X: medial border of the insertion of the posterior cruciate ligament. (B) White line: dorsal condylar line of the tibia. (C) White X: midpoint of the insertion of the patellar tendon.

TT-TG measurement. The TT-TG distance is the mediolateral distance between the midpoint of the insertion of the patellar tendon and the trochlear groove parallel to the dorsal femoral condylar line. dFCL, dorsal femoral condylar line; TG, trochlear groove; TT, tibial tubercle; TT-TG, tibial tubercle–trochlear groove distance.

Femur torsion. The femur torsion is the angle between a line through the center of the femoral head and neck and the dorsal femoral condylar line. (A) White line: line through the center of the femoral head and neck. (B) White line: dorsal femoral condylar line.

Tibia torsion. The tibia torsion is the angle between the dorsal tibia condylar line and a line through the medial and lateral malleolus. (A) White line: dorsal tibia condylar line. (B) White line: line through the medial and lateral malleolus.

Alignment of the leg. The alignment of the leg is the angle between a line from the center of the femoral head to the center of the knee and a line from the center of the ankle to the center of the knee.

Knee joint rotation. The knee joint rotation is the angle between the dorsal femoral condylar line and the dorsal tibia condylar line. dFCL, dorsal femoral condylar line; dTCL, dorsal tibia condylar line.
Lateral patellar tilt angle. The lateral patellar tilt angle is the angle between the trochlea line and the patella line. LPTA, lateral patellar tilt angle.
Sulcus angle. The sulcus angle is the angle between the medial and lateral trochlea wall. α, sulcus angle.

sec.title: Image Acquisition
sec.p: The MRI scans were performed using a Philips Panorama 1.0T open magnetic resonance system. The patients were placed supine, with hip and knee joints extended to 0° and their feet fastened to a foot plate, the design of which imposed an approximate 15° of external rotation. Separate Velcro® straps were fastened around the ankle joint, as well as proximal and distal to the knee joint, to avoid movement of the patient. Images were taken from the hip, the knee, and the ankle. Both knee joints were placed simultaneously in a SENSE Body/Spine XL coil (Philips). We used a T1-weighted fast-field-echo (FFE) sequence with an echo time of 10 ms and a repetition time of 748 ms. The field of view was set to 375 mm, the slice thickness to 4 mm, the slice gap to 0.5 mm, the flip angle to 60°, and the image matrix to 368 × 294 pixels. The acquisition of 25 slices took a mean of 3 minutes 41 seconds.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: All relevant data were entered in a spreadsheet program and analyzed statistically using Minitab 15 software (Minitab, Inc, State College, Pennsylvania). An unpaired t test was performed to determine significant differences between the different parameters of the patient and control groups as well as for the subgroups TT-TG < and ≥ 20 mm and TT-PCL < and ≥ 24 mm. A P value of less than .05 was considered significant. In addition, the Pearson correlation coefficient was calculated.

We also evaluated the intraclass correlation coefficient (ICC) for multiple measurements by different observers on different specimens.2 The ICC values range from 0 to 1, with a value approaching 1 indicating better agreement. An ICC value higher than 0.75 indicates excellent agreement.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The TT-PCL distance measurement showed excellent agreement for intraobserver variability (ICC-intra >0.93) and almost excellent agreement for interobserver variability (ICC-inter >0.74). As the reference points for the measurement were located on the tibia only, influence from the shape of the trochlear groove could be excluded.

A statistically significant difference (P < .00001) was found between the TT-PCL distance of the patient group (mean [SD], 21.9 [4.30] mm) and the control group (18.4 [3.35] mm) (Figure 10). The mean (SD) TT-TG was 18.9 (5.16) mm in the patient group and 11.9 (4.67) mm in the control group (P < .00001) (Table 1). There was no strong correlation (R2 = 0.34) between TT-PCL and TT-TG.

caption.p: Box plot of tibial tubercle–posterior cruciate ligament (TT-PCL) control group vs patient group.
Comparison of Control vs Patient Groupsa

fn.label: a
fn.p: AL, angle between a line from the center of the femoral head to the center of the knee and a line from the center of the ankle to the center of the knee; KJ rot, the rotation of the knee joint; LPTA, lateral patellar tilt angle; Min, minimum; Max, maximum; TT-PCL, tibial tubercle–posterior cruciate ligament; TT-TG, tibial tubercle–trochlear groove.

sec.p: In the control group, 95% of the measured TT-PCL values were less than 24 mm. Among the subgroup of participants with a pathological (≥20 mm) TT-TG distance (40 knee joints), 43% (17 knee joints) had a normal (<24 mm) TT-PCL.

The subgroup of patients with a TT-TG ≥20 mm showed a significantly higher LPTA (P = .003) and sulcus angle (P = .04) and a trend to a higher knee joint rotation (P = .076) compared with patients with a TT-TG <20 mm. Femur torsion (P = .393), tibia torsion (P = .338), and leg alignment (P = .469) were not significantly different (Table 2). The subgroup of patients with a TT-PCL ≥24 mm had a higher sulcus angle (P = .042) compared with patients with a TT-PCL <24 mm. All the other parameters were not different (femur torsion, P = .651; tibia torsion, P = .534; leg alignment, P = .335; knee joint rotation, P = .750; and LPTA, P = .221) (Table 3). The TT-TG had a low correlation with knee joint rotation (R2 = 0.1775), LPTA (R2 = 0.3628), and sulcus angle (R2 = 0.1693), whereas the TT-PCL had no correlation to either of these parameters.

fn.label: a
fn.p: AL, angle between a line from the center of the femoral head to the center of the knee and a line from the center of the ankle to the center of the knee; KJ rot, the rotation of the knee joint; LPTA, lateral patellar tilt angle; Min, minimum; Max, maximum; TT-PCL, tibial tubercle–posterior cruciate ligament; TT-TG, tibial tubercle–trochlear groove.

fn.label: a
fn.p: AL, angle between a line from the center of the femoral head to the center of the knee and a line from the center of the ankle to the center of the knee; KJ rot, the rotation of the knee joint; LPTA, lateral patellar tilt angle; Min, minimum; Max, maximum; TT-PCL, tibial tubercle–posterior cruciate ligament; TT-TG, tibial tubercle–trochlear groove.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The TT-PCL distance had excellent and almost excellent intraobserver and interobserver variability, even though only one of the examiners was an experienced radiologist and one observer had only poor MRI experience.

We consider a TT-PCL distance <24 mm as normal, based on our data. This implies that 43% (17 of 40) of the knee joints with a pathological TT-TG distance (≥20 mm) had a normal position of the tibial tubercle. This is a possible explanation why there is no strong correlation between the TT-PCL and the TT-TG.

According to our data, there is a correlation between the TT-TG with the rotation of the knee joint and the sulcus angle. The TT-PCL has no correlation to either of these parameters. This could be evidence that the TT-TG alignment may occur proximal to the tibial tubercle in some patients. This finding is supported by the trend to higher knee joint rotation in patients with a TT-TG ≥20 mm.

Importantly, the measurement could also be performed on standard axial MRI of the knee, which is often required in these patients to exclude cartilage damage or to evaluate soft tissue injury. Furthermore, the distance was unaffected by the shape of the trochlea.

We chose the medial boarder of the PCL as a reference point because it was easy to find. Akagi et al1 described the center of the posterior cruciate ligament as a reference point to measure the anteroposterior axis of the tibia. In our experience, it was sometimes difficult to find the correct center of the irregular-shaped posterior cruciate ligament.

There are some limitations to our study. We calculated the normal value of the TT-PCL distance based on the anatomy of 60 knee joints. The threshold for a normal TT-PCL could therefore change considerably in a larger population. Because of the small number of patients who had a pathological TT-TG distance (TT-TG ≥20 mm; 40 patients), this subgroup is too small to draw definitive conclusions regarding the incidence of tibial tubercle lateralization. The alignment of the leg was measured with the participants in supine position without weightbearing.

In conclusion, we believe that a pathological TT-TG distance is an excellent parameter for identifying patients with patellar malalignment but should not automatically lead to a distal realignment procedure. The TT-PCL distance is an alternative method for determining the lateral displacement of the tibial tubercle. It is not influenced by the rotation of the knee or the shape of the trochlea. On the basis of our data, we consider a TT-PCL distance ≥24 mm as abnormal.

ack.p: We thank Dr Peter Schmidt and his team for conducting the MRI examination.
